programmes.show_description: Elton John, Iggy Pop and Bernie Taupin are among the rock stars paying homage in this cinematic bio-doc about the notorious rocker Alice Cooper.
1987: It's farewells all round as The Tube ends and The Smiths split. Goth rock peaks with The Mission and Siouxsie. Plus, hits from Depeche Mode and The Cure. (5 of 5)
Nevermind: Surviving band members Krist Novoselic and Dave Grohl discuss the creation of their seminal album that defined a genre, and the legacy of Kurt Cobain.
Bagpipes: A Celebration showcases Scotland's iconic bagpipe music with stunning landscapes, top pipe bands, soloists, and rich musical history.

programmes.show_name: Nicola Benedetti & Friends From The Ulster Hall
programmes.show_description: Join Nicola Benedetti for a unique and personal show as she returns to the stage at the Ulster Hall for her first solo tour in over ten years.
In The Cards: Fortuneteller Madame Myra thinks she is on to a winner when she meets a man prophesied to come in to a lot of money before dying shortly after. (S8, ep 2)
Nothin' Short Of Highway Robbery: On a long drive through the desert, a couple get their car serviced and are handed an extortionate bill. But they plan on turning the tables. (S8, ep 3)
Scrimshaw: Brenda, a lonely alcoholic, is delighted when she bumps into an old friend from university. But does he have an ulterior motive for seeing her? (S8, ep 4)
Skeleton In The Cupboard: Robert Smythe has a dark secret he has kept for 20 years but it has now come back to haunt him. Can he keep it a secret from his wife? (S9, ep 1)
The Evil of Adelaide Winters: A man believes a woman running a psychic scam has contacted his dead son and becomes dangerously obsessed with her sessions. (S2, ep 16)
Ouse Valley Viaduct: Stephen Mangan presents the semi-final of Landscape Artist of the Year at the historic Ouse Valley Viaduct in Sussex. (S11, ep 7)
Stirring reinvention of the show, celebrated the world over for its award-winning music and the thrilling energy and passion of its Irish and international dance.

programmes.show_name: Rod Stewart: It Had To Be You
programmes.show_description: Filmed in front of a live studio audience at Sony Studios in New York City, Rod Stewart performs songs from his recent release "It Had to be You: The Great American Songbook".
Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks perform in Boston in 2004 as part of their sensational Say You Will tour. (1 of 2)
Mick Fleetwood, John McVie, Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks perform in Boston in 2004 as part of their sensational Say You Will tour. (2 of 2)
New. Telling the story of Icarus, whose wings melt when he flies too close to the sun, sending him crashing into the volcanic and mysterious world of Varekai. (2003)
Documentary capturing the sights and sounds of the pivotal year in Elvis's journey to become the King of Rock 'n' Roll. Features rare footage, photos and recordings.

programmes.show_name: Chuck Berry: The King Of Rock N' Roll
programmes.show_description: Film from award-winner Jon Brewer granting unprecedented access into the life of the rock icon. Featuring John Lennon and Alice Cooper.
Prepare to be blown away by performances from Opry members Ringo Starr, Rhonda Vincent, Mickey Guyton, Mandy Barnett and Molly Tuttle.
Coat of Many Colors: Country singing sensation Dolly Parton looks back at six of her most famous songs, discussing their inspiration, impact, legacy and accolades. (1 of 6)
Jolene: Country star Dolly Parton looks back at her early career moves and discusses the inspiration behind her song Jolene, which has been covered by more than 400 artists. (2 of 6)
I Will Always Love You: Dolly Parton discusses the success of I Will Always Love You, and why denying Elvis the chance to cover it became one of her savviest business moves. (3 of 6)
It's All Wrong, But It's Alright: Dolly Parton recalls how she shocked the country scene with her 1978 hit It's All Wrong, But It's Alright. With Miley Cyrus and Lily Tomlin. (4 of 6)
9 To 5: Dolly Parton reflects on her Oscar-nominated song 9 To 5 and the challenges of acting in Hollywood. With her 9 to 5 co-star Lily Tomlin and goddaughter Miley Cyrus. (5 of 6)
Travelin' Thru: Dolly Parton reflects on the conservative backlash to her hit Travelin' Thru, how she came to be seen as a gay activist and her transition from country to pop. (6 of 6)

programmes.show_name: Johnny Cash: The Man In Black In Britain
programmes.show_description: Documentary exploring Johnny Cash's connection with Britain, featuring testimonies from his own children and friends like Elvis Costello.
The Who give a first-hand insight into the making of their 20th century masterpiece, Who's Next, as well as discussing its far-reaching influence.
Sir Simon Rattle conducts Sibelius' tone poems and Bruckner's radiant Seventh Symphony, where vast landscapes merge with the human soul.
Golden Glow: Bob perfectly demonstrates how to make a snow scene glow as he paints a glistening pond in the dead of winter. (S11, ep 11)
Roadside Barn: In this masterpiece, Bob follows an old dirt road up to a quaint country barn nestled in nature's greenery. (S11, ep 12)
In The Cards: Fortuneteller Madame Myra thinks she is on to a winner when she meets a man prophesied to come in to a lot of money before dying shortly after. (S8, ep 2)
Nothin' Short Of Highway Robbery: On a long drive through the desert, a couple get their car serviced and are handed an extortionate bill. But they plan on turning the tables. (S8, ep 3)
The Case of Mr Pelham: A reoccurring flow of troubling incidents leads Mr Pelham to believe there is someone impersonating him. (S1, ep 11)
Guilty Witness: When the Cranes hear the Verbers locked in a fierce argument in the apartment above, the disappearance of Mr Verber the next day raises eyebrows. (S1, ep 12)
A fascinating look at the life and career of Oscar-nominated director John Sturges, the mind behind classic films such as The Great Escape and The Magnificent Seven. (S3, ep 1)
A fascinating portrait of Yul Brynner, the Academy Award-winning actor famed for his roles as King Mongkut of Siam in The King and I and a robotic gunslinger in Westworld. (S6, ep 9)
Scrimshaw: Brenda, a lonely alcoholic, is delighted when she bumps into an old friend from university. But does he have an ulterior motive for seeing her? (S8, ep 4)
Skeleton In The Cupboard: Robert Smythe has a dark secret he has kept for 20 years but it has now come back to haunt him. Can he keep it a secret from his wife? (S9, ep 1)

programmes.show_name: Celebrity Portrait Artist Of The Year 2019
programmes.show_description: Mark Gatiss and other celebrities showcase their artistic skills by painting Denise Lewis, Laurence Fox and Martha Plimpton.
Ouse Valley Viaduct: Stephen Mangan presents the semi-final of Landscape Artist of the Year at the historic Ouse Valley Viaduct in Sussex. (S11, ep 7)
An intriguing look into the life and career of Academy Award-winning film director Sidney Lumet. (S3, ep 2)
An eye-opening look at the life and career of four-time Academy Award nominee Claude Rains, the English actor who appeared in Casablanca and Lawrence of Arabia. (S6, ep 10)
The Colonel's Lady: Colonel George Peregrine's comfortable life is disturbed when his wife writes a bestselling raunchy novel. Is this evidence that she's having an affair? (S9, ep 2)
The Surgeon: When wealthy Prince Zawi gives surgeon Robert Sandy a diamond for saving his life, the doctor finds that his new jewel is really more of a liability than an asset. (S9, ep 3)
Santa Claus and the Tenth Avenue Kid: While working as a department store Santa Claus, a paroled convict tries to help a troubled boy. (S1, ep 13)
The Cheney Vase: After being fired from his job at an art museum, Lyle Endicott must come up with a plan to keep himself afloat. (S1, ep 14)

programmes.show_name: Andre Rieu: Dancing Through the Skies
programmes.show_description: The world-famous violinist's mesmerising concert from the Semper Opera House in Dresden, featuring spectacular waltzes and arias and music from Phantom Of The Opera.

programmes.show_name: Classic FM Live: A Film Music Spectacular
programmes.show_description: The Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra and the Ukranian conductor Kirill Karabits perform film themes from The Royal Albert Hall including Star Wars, Jurassic Park and more.
